msContents.summary: 1 copy of Dārābnāmah by Abū Ṭāhir Ṭarsūsī, Muḥammad ibn Ḥasan

author.persName: Abū Ṭāhir Ṭarsūsī, Muḥammad ibn Ḥasan
ابو طاهر طرسوسى، محمد ابن حسن

msItem.title: Dārābnāmah
داراب نامه
msItem.note: Containing only the first part of the work, namely, the story of Dārāb

listBibl.bibl: For a more detailed description see Rieu 1895, no 385.

msItem.decoNote: f. 1v Zāl with Rustam and his other two sons.
f. 2r (above). Rustam standing at the edge of the pit of spears shooting Shaghād. (below). Rūdābeh watching as Zāl sends his army under Farāmurz against Bahnam at Kabul.
f. 2v Zāl imprisoned in a suspended cage by order of Bahman. Mahesh.
f. 3r Ardashīr receiving Tāj Ārā'ī and Humāy (her daughter) when he selected Humāy as his wife at the harem.
f. 3v Bahman and his horse being swallowed by a dragon.
f. 4r Hurmuz, the launderer who rescued Dārāb as an infant, washing clothes in the river.
f. 4v Dārāb displaying his strenght by throwing a bleacher's or fuller's club in the air, watched by Hurmuz.
f. 5r Dārāb lifting Hurmuz.
f. 5v Dārāb defeating Gharjeh. Mahesh.
f. 6r Dārāb and Ẓuḥḥāk in battle with their respective armies. Lālū.
f. 7v Dārāb brought before his mother, Humāy. Mithrā.
f. 10r Ẓuḥḥāk carried in a litter to Humāy's palace. Iḳbāl.
f. 11v Humāy playing polo with her slaves. Sānwlah.
f. 12r Dārāb meeting Humāy on the polo ground. Mithrā.
f. 12v Dārāb playing polo. Bhīnī.
f. 14r The murdered Jahrūn brought before Humāy by his servants who are asking for justice (attribution cut off).
f. 15r Humāy fainting as the fettered Dārāb is brought before her. Nānhā.
f. 16r Dārāb left by Ẓuḥḥāk to face the dragon. Nānhā.
f. 17v Dārāb attacking the dīv, Samandūn, whose brothers Ḳanṭarash and Kumūz, are watching.
f. 18r Dārāb brought as a prisoner before Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Shīvdās.
f. 19v Dārāb in bed between Ṭahrūsiyyeh and 'Anṭūshiyyeh. Bhagwān.
f. 20v Dārāb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh in a boat. Bhūreh.
f. 21r Dārāb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh watching a battle between the Zangi army and bears on the Island of Angaliyun. Paras.
f. 21v The battle continued. Paras.
f. 22r The battle continued. Paras.
f. 23r Dārāb asking the sage for the name of the Island of Shish Mināreth. Bhagwān.
f. 23v Dārāb at the top of the minaret while the sage explains to Ṭahrūsiyyeh that whoever enters the tower cannot escape. Bhagwān.
f. 24r 'Umar entertaining Dārāb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh to a meal in his tent. Nānhā.

f. 25v Dārāb drawing the mighty bow of Isfandiyār before Sangarūn. The severed head of the son of the ruler of the Island of Katrun is fixed to the wall above. He was beheaded because he failed to draw the bow. Bhagwān.
f. 26r Khavārīḳ and Ṭahrūsiyyeh before the Zangi king and his wife while pages and slaves are seized by the Zangis who later ate them. Mādhū Khurd.
f. 27r Dārāb, having thrown Hamangū to the giant fish, sleeps in the enclosure of Khavārīḳ. Mādhū Khurd.
Khavārīḳ attacking the Zangi king on his throne. Mādhū Khurd.
f. 28r Khavārīḳ and the pilgrim looking down at Dārāb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh after putting them in the well on the false pretext of Dārāb's drunkenness. Tulūk.
f. 28v Dārāb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh coming before the zāhid after they had escaped from Khavārīḳ who had tortured them. Nānhā.
f. 29r Ṭahrūsiyyeh watching Dārāb throwing Ṭanbalūs, brother of Ḳanṭarush, into the water. Ibrāhīm Ḳahhār.
f. 29v Mihrāsb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh watching Dārāb fighting the Zangis. The body of Ṭanbalūs is floating in the water. Ibrāhīm Ḳahhār.
f. 30r Dārāb (disguised as a merchant) and Mihrāsb brought before Shāhū, son of Ṭanbalūs. Nānhā.
f. 31r Dārāb in a boat, with Majallat holding an astrolabe and standing on a bank. Elephants carrying wood nearby. Jagan.
f. 32r Dārāb looking at the dishes of food left by the sun-worshippers on the mountain. Farrukh Khurd.
f. 32v The battle between the armies of Dilkunād and Kandarūn which was waged with hooks on ropes. Farrukh Khurd.
f. 33r Dārāb going into battle against the Zangis (attribution partly cut off). Probably Narāyan.
f. 33v Dārāb receiving homage from the defeated Zangis. Narāyan.
f. 34r Shāpūr who helped Ṭahrūsiyyeh search for Dārāb telling her that all the slaves have been sold. Basāwan.
f. 35r Mihrāsb having lost all his possessions and become a woodcutter found Ṭahrūsiyyeh in Shāpūr's house. Nānhā.
f. 35v Mihrāsb comforting Ṭahrūsiyyeh who is overcome by joy at seeing him. Nānhā.
f. 36r Shāpūr and Ṭahrūsiyyeh embracing at Nurūz watched by Mihrāsb who crouches in the woodstore holding a book and an astrolabe. Banwāri Kalān.
f. 37r Shāpūr returning to his house to find it ransacked. Sarwan.
f. 38r Mihrāsb and Shāpūr fighting after Shāpūr had accused Mihrāsb of ransacking his room. Dhanū.
f. 39r Mihrāsb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh throwing Shāpūr into the sea. Sānwlah.
f. 39v Mihrāsb opening the door into the walled garden. Sānwlah.
f. 41r Mihrāsb making love to an ape to placate it and save his own life and that of Ṭahrūsiyyeh in the land of fierce apes. Dhanū.
f. 41v Ṭahrūsiyyeh carrying Mihrāsb from the apes' palace. Dhanū.
f. 42v The apes sailing in turtle shells and carrying fishbone weapons attacking the boat in which Ṭahrūsiyyeh is travelling. One defender has a gun. Bhūreh.
f. 43v Ṭahrūsiyyeh weeping by the bound Mihrāsb under the Waḳwāḳ Tree. Narāyan.
f. 44r Ṭahrūsiyyeh and Mihrāsb under the Waḳwāḳ Tree. Mukhliṣ.
f. 45r Mihrāsb and the water maiden on the roof of the hut with Ṭahrūsiyyeh nearby. Dharmdās.
f. 45v The water people bringing pearls from the sea watched by Ṭahrūsiyyeh, Mihrāsb and the water maiden on the hut. Dharmdās.
f. 46r The water maiden's husband, insane with jealousy because of her love for Mihrāsb, tearing their children's bodies apart in front of her, watched by Mihrāsb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Kesū Kalān.
f. 47r The watchman on the tower of the Island of Malakūt warning the one-eyed people of Mihrāsb's approach by ringing a bell. Sarwan.
f. 47v Sīṭarūsh, who knew all languages, questioning Mihrāsb in Pahlavi, watched by four of the one-eyed people. Sarwan.
f. 48v Gauhar-āsā, widow of Farṭalūs, accusing the bound Sīṭarūsh of placing Mihrāsb on the throne to succeed her husband as King of Malakūt. Nānhā.
f. 49r Gauhar-āsā having been killed by a cobra in her husband's tomb is discovered by her daughters. Sarjan.
f. 49v Mihrāsb's supporters killing the daughter of Farṭalūs and her supporters. Sarjan.
f. 50v Dārāb ordering Liknād to release Mihrāsb. Nānhā.
f. 51v A gigantic white serpent drinking watched by Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Mukhliṣ.
f. 52r The parents of the white serpent who were in the form of human-headed winged serpents greeting Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Bhagwān.
f. 52v The winged serpents relating their story to Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Bhagwān.
f. 54r Ṭahrūsiyyeh brought before Zangdilīsā, the queen of the Zangis. (Attribution cut) Bhureh?.
f. 54v Ṭahrūsiyyeh and Zangdilīsā in a boat.
f. 55r Zangdilīsā offering wine to Ṭahrūsiyyeh in the boat. Chaturbhūj.
f. 56v (above). Ṭahrūsiyyeh thrown into the sea by Zangdilīsā's maidens. Manī. (below). Two men rescuing Ṭahrūsiyyeh from the sea. Manī.
f. 58v Ṭahrūsiyyeh weeping by the shore is comforted by Satarūn's slave who are offering her food. Chaturbhūj.
f. 59v Ṭahrūsiyyeh recognising Zangdilīsā in the house of Haranḳālīs the Greek, where she had been left by Sanṭāraḳ. Shankar.
f. 62r Haranḳālīs embracing Ṭahrūsiyyeh having discovered her to be his niece. Bhagwān.
f. 63r Miniature lost except for the lower half of a seated man on the left and dishes on the right. Sarjan.
f. 64v Ṭahrūsiyyeh posing as an envoy in an attempt to end the fighting between Dārāb and Faṣṭaliḳīn. Mithrā.
f. 65v Dārāb fainting as he recognises Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Mithrā.
f. 66v Gifts being brought to Dārāb from the besieged fortress including an elephant mounted on wheels. Sānwlah.
f. 67r Dārāb enthroned receiving the gifts brought by the envoy Shalshalīyūn, including the elephant on wheels. Nānhā.
f. 68r Ṭahrūsiyyeh in disguise with her uncle Faṣṭaliḳīn in the besieged fortress. Ibrāhīm Lāhorī.

f. 69v Dārāb kneeling beside Hartafālis and looking at Faṣṭaliḳīn who lies stabbed before the idol. 'Abḳarhūd, who is shown hurrying away, had dreamed of this incident and awoken to find it all true.
f. 70v 'Antūshiyyeh, mother of Ṭahrūsiyyeh receiving 'Abḳarhūd. Outline by Kālū Lāhorī and faces by Ibrāhīm Ḳahhār.
f. 73r 'Abḳarhūd ordering soldiers to go to the prison and murder Ṭahrūsiyyeh and Kharīṭīnūs. Tiriyyā.
f. 73v Kharīṭīnūs and the daughter of the gaoler's wife (who was substituted for Ṭahrūsiyyeh) lying dead before 'Abḳarhūd who did not know of the deception. Tiriyyā.
f. 74r 'Abḳarhūd being acclaimed king by his followers. Mādhū Khurd.
f. 75r Ṭahrūsiyyeh feasting with the gaoler and his wife and a sailor who did not recognise her. Dhanū.

f. 76v (above). Dārāb and Hartafālis waiting with twenty men under the ramparts in a boat until the sailor could guide them across the moat into the fortress. (below). Reunion of Dārāb and Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Mukhliṣ.
f. 77v Miniature by Narāyan lost except for part of a boat.
f. 78v Dārāb receiving Ṭahrūsiyyeh's aged grandmother while 'Abḳarhūd stands bound in the foreground. Karm Chand.
f. 79v Dārāb enthroned with Ṭahrūsiyyeh beside him. Kālū Lāhorī.
f. 80v Ṭahrūsiyyeh telling Dārāb about 'Abḳarhūd's murderous plot as he stands bound before them. Sarwan and Paras.
f. 81r Dārāb celebrating his accession to the kingdom of Ḥanṭarash. Kesū Ḳahhār.
f. 82r Dārāb watching 'Abḳarhūd being tortured. Mukhliṣ.
f. 82v 'Anṭūshiyyeh and Hartafālis asking the idol oracle the fate of Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Mukhliṣ.
f. 83r Dārāb watching the reunion between Ṭahrūsiyyeh and her mother, 'Anṭūshiyyeh. Bhūreh.
f. 83v Zangdilīsā and the Zangis arriving by boat watched by Ṭahrūsiyyeh. Bhūreh.
f. 84v During the quarrel between the crews of the boats Ṭahrūsiyyeh is killed by Zangdilīsā. Farrukh Khurd.
f. 85r Dārāb and Haranḳālīs discover the body of Ṭahrūsiyyeh in the boat with her baby. Shankar.
f. 85v The weeping Dārāb being rowed home whilst Ṭahrūsiyyeh's coffin and a woman holding her baby are in another boat with Zangdilīsā.
f. 87r Dārāb, watched by Haranḳālīs, having consulted the idol oracle to find out the cause of Ṭahrūsiyyeh's death tying Liknād's arms. Chaturbhūj.

f. 88r (above). Zangdilīsā and Liknād dying as the result of snakebite on 'Arūs Island watched by the countryman who was the only witness of their death. (below). Mihrāsb, by now old and feeble, rescued from the chest by Dārāb on the Island of Malakūt.
f. 88v Mihrāsb, blinded by being in the dark so long, being robed and having his eyes attended to by order of Dārāb. Dārāb is being shown the magic stone brought from Mt. Balāvarān. Paras.
f. 89v Dārāb in a boat on his way to Iran to see his mother Humāy. Khem Ḳarān.
f. 90r Dārāb, reunited with his year-old-son, in a boat with Haranḳālīs, 'Anṭūshiyyeh and Maṭrūshiyyeh on their way to Ḥanṭarash. Mahesh.
f. 90v Dārāb and his son watching one of the boats accompanying them being wrecked off the Arabian coast near Mt. 'Umān. Mahesh.
f. 91r Dārāb's child playing with his nurse at an inn after being saved from the shipwreck. Bhagwān.
f. 91v The inkeeper watching Dārāb who is raking the caravansarai. Bhagwān.
f. 92v Dārāb fighting the slaveboys whose taunting had infuriated him. Farrukh Chela.
f. 93v The merchant having learned Dārāb's story ordered a private room for him in the caravansarai. Farrukh Chela.
f. 94r Dārāb praying in the temple where he had gone to seek divine guidance. Bhureh.
f. 94v Dārāb with the aged fuller and Jānispar before Muṣṭaliḳ, the King of Rabat.
f. 95v Dārāb and his companions eating in a caravansarai having left Muṣṭaliḳ. Tārā.
f. 96r Muṣṭaliḳ and his vizier Shūyarbak, before Dārāb. Outline by Mādhū Kalān, portraits by Chaturbhūj.
f. 98r 'Anṭūshiyyeh discovering the body of Muṣṭaliḳ after he had been murdered by his two sons. Nānhā.
f. 98v 'Anṭūshiyyeh, Mihtantasiyyeh and a suckling child in the house as Dārāb rides off to rescue Humāy from the Ḳaiṣar of Rūm. Nānhā.
f. 99v Humāy being seized and bound by order of the Ḳaiṣar of Rūm. Mithrā.
f. 100v Dārāb pulling up a tree to use as a weapon as Humāy is abducted by Kuh Āsā and the Ḳaiṣar of Rūm. Miskīneh.
f. 101r Dārāb untying Humāy's bonds after he defeated Kuh Āsā and his men. Mādhū Khurd.
f. 102r Dārāb, with Humāy beside him, throwing rocks at the Ḳaiṣar of Rūm's army. On the right the Ḳaiṣar is shown with Kuh Āsā. Ibrāhīm Ḳahhār.
f. 102v Rashnavād walking in the tomb in the city of Ray, where he hid, to find himself being bound up by his son, neither recognising the other. Ibrāhīm Ḳahhār.
f. 103v Rashnavād having been abandoned by the Ḳaiṣar's men on Mt. Tabark near Ray telling Dārāb and Humāy of his adventures. Work by Bihzād, corrected by 'Abd al-Ṣamad.
f. 104v A council of war between the treacherous Iranians and Kuh Āsā secretly watched by Dārāb, Humāy and Rashnavād. Dhanū.
f. 105r Dārāb watched by Humāy and Rashnavād, attacking the Ḳaiṣar's army with a tree trunk. Ibrāhīm Ḳahhār.
f. 106r Dārāb continuing his battle with the Ḳaiṣar's army. Tulsī Kalān.
f. 106v The goat, sent in answer to their prayers, which saved Humāy and Rashnavād from thirst (attribution cut). Probably Tulsī Kalān.
f. 107v Humāy and Rashnavād arriving at the house of Nūrshān, the merchant who hid them. Ibrāhīm Lāhorī.
f. 108r Nūrshān and his wife entertaining Humāy and Rashnavād. Sānwlah.
f. 108v Humāy, having been recognised as the Queen fo the Iranians, being honoured in the house of Yulīmān, the goldsmith. Sānwlah.
f. 109v Humāy promising Yulīmān he will be appointed amīr of Ray as a reward while Ghammāz the traitor who informed on the m stands behind him. Chaturbhūj.
f. 110r Ghammāz telling his story to the Ḳaiṣar who disbelieves him and orders him to be bound (attribution cut).
f. 111r Ghammāz captured by Yulīmān and brought before Humāy and Rashnavād as the traitor who tried to reveal their whereabouts to the Ḳaiṣar. Paras Ḳahhār.

f. 111v Neighbours of Yulīmān reading a letter and discovering the body of Ghammāz who had been killed by Yulīmān who himself then fled with Humāy and Rashnavād. Humāy ordered Yulīmān to leave a letter on the body telling of Ghammāz's treachery. Paras Ḳahhār.
f. 112v The dragon outside its mountain cave explaining to Dārāb that it had been sent by God as His servant on earth. Narāyan.
f. 113r The reunion of Dārāb (dismounting from his horse) with Humāy and Rashnavād watched by the dragon. Ḳesū Ḳahhār.
f. 113v Humāy presenting Dārāb as her successor to the throne of Iran. Ḳesū Ḳahhār.
f. 114r Humāy watched by Dārāb as she dictates letters announcing Dārāb's accession and appoints Yulīmān to be amīr of Ray and Rashnavād to be Dārāb's personal assistant. Dharmdās.
f. 114v Dārāb leading his army against the Ḳaiṣar of Rūm. Dharmdās.
f. 115v The Ḳaiṣar falling from his elephant and Dārāb recapturing the Iranian standard from the standard bearer. Jagan.
f. 116r Rashnavād bringin the Ḳaiṣar as a prisoner before Humāy and Dārāb (attribution cut).
f. 117r Dārāb receiving a letter from Failaḳūs, brother of the Ḳaiṣar of Rūm. Mithrā.
f. 117v The Turanians buliding the city of Dārābgīrd in the sea, as part of their reparations, directed by Dārāb. Mithrā.
f. 118v Humāy's groom, who had a secret passion for her, murdering her at night when she would not submit to him. Manī.
f. 119v Dārāb having his armour put on before he set out to avenge the murder of Rashnavād. Bhagwān.
f. 120v (above). Dārāb attacking Shu'aib, the Arab who had killed Rashnavād. (below). Dārāb carrying Shu'aib away.
f. 121r Shu'aib about to be executed reminds Dārāb that they are both descended from the lines of Ẓuḥḥāk and Jamshīd and is pardoned by Dārāb. Tiriyyā.
f. 122r Failaḳūs and Shu'aib together. Jagan.
f. 123r Dārāb receiving the homage of Failaḳūs and Shu'aib. Mukhliṣ.
f. 123v Dārāb realising the treachery of Failaḳūs and Shu'aib seizing them both by their throats during the meal. Mukhliṣ.
f. 126r Failaḳūs reunited with his family, embracing his wife. Shīvdās.

f. 127r Dārāb capturing the town of 'Amuriyeh where Failaḳūs lived. Failaḳūs is shown on the roof which had been decorated with arms and standards to deceive Dārāb into thinking the fortress was heavily guarded. Manī.
Filāsūn, vizier to Failaḳūs bringing gifts to Dārāb. Darkeh.
Dārāb rejecting Nāhid, daughter of Failaḳūs, who was offered in marriage to him.

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on Ch. Rieu: Supplement to the Catalogue of the Persian Manuscripts in the British Museum. London, 1895

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact British Library, Registering for a Reader Pass. Contact apac-enquiries@bl.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript. For information on catalogues and ordering manuscripts see Finding and ordering Persian manuscripts in the British Library.
